Problem:
class EmailClient { constructor(server) { this.server = server; this.cache = []; } sendEmail(message, recipient) { if (this.server.isConnected()) { this.server.send(message, recipient); this.cache.push({message, recipient}); return true; } return false; } retrieveEmails() { if (this.server.isConnected()) { const emails = this.server.fetch(); this.cache = emails.concat(this.cache); return emails; } return []; } } class Server { constructor() { this.connected = true; } isConnected() { return this.connected; } connect() { this.connected = true; } disconnect() { this.connected = false; } send(message, recipient) { console.log(`Sending message to ${recipient}: ${message}`); } fetch() { console.log('Fetching emails'); return [{ message: 'Hello', recipient: 'user@example.com' }]; } }",

If the server loses connection, will the EmailClient still successfully send emails?
Explanation: In the sendEmail method of EmailClient, the server’s connection status is checked by calling this.server.isConnected(). If the server is not connected, the method returns false, indicating that the email cannot be sent.

List only distinct and meaningful causal relations. Do not provide any final answer to the question. Focus only on extracting the causal structure. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "A → B; C → D; ..."}.
causal_map: EmailClient.sendEmail → Server.isConnected; Server.isConnected → EmailClient.sendEmail; Server.send → EmailClient.cache; Server.fetch → EmailClient.cache; Server.connect → Server.isConnected; Server.disconnect → Server.isConnected
causal_integration_prompt: You are an expert in causal reasoning. Do not provide any final answer to the question. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "<concise natural-language causal description>"}.
causal_map_integration: The connection status of the server influences the ability of the EmailClient to send emails, as the EmailClient can only send emails if the server is connected.
